Although we are mainly interested in Saskatchewan, the questionnaire does deal with the diet of pioneers of Western Canada generally, so your recollections of experiences in Manitoba will be welcomed.

WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.)

Name Mrs. Geo. E. Roy
Address Carman, Sask.
Birthplace East Kildonan, Man.

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1911
Where did you set up housekeeping? & S. 17.12.7 W.3.12 rel. 4½ y. Windshus sack
Where had you been living before that? Winnipeg
For how many people did you prepare meals? four st. young, two hired men
How far was it to your nearest store? 12 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? About once a week
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? flour, sugar, tea, dried fruits, salt.

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Lake of the Woods, good grade
I think we used to buy flour named 4x in the early days
Was flour milled locally? No
How far away? Where 20-30 mile
What year? Can't remember
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour?
How much did you use Graham flour? Whenever I could get it
Whole wheat flour? Yes
Was flour milled locally? No
How far away? Where 20-30 mile
What year? Can't remember
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? Can't remember
What other grain products did you use? lentils, oatmeal

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Pork cured in summer beef in winter.

How did you get fresh meat? Butcher shop in town.

How often did you get fresh meat? Not very often.

How did you preserve meat? Pork in salt bin, also fried down fresh pork packed in crock lined with the fat that fried out.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? Yes.

If so what year was it organized? 1920 and it has run every year since.

Did you use game? No.

How much did it cost? About $5.00 per ton.

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible. We now have our own wood lot on our farm and we get a car of coal every winter from Tofield, Alta. Several neighbors going in with us on the car of coal.

16. **SHAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS**

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

When I was very young I can remember a customer buying sugar and using his own clean bandana handkerchief to wrap it in. Small articles were put in square pieces of paper made into cornucopia shape and folded in at top. Jam was in small wooden packs and syrup in large wooden packs. Baking molasses was in large bags with a few tacks on own container along side. We used to go to store at Lower Portage, across the river.

17. Give a typical day's meal (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

**Breakfast:** porridge, oatmeal, milk, bread, butter.

**Dinner:** potatoes, other vegetable, rice pudding, milk, bread, butter.

**Supper:** bread and milk—hot.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in eastern Canada?

1941........... Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

**Roast chicken—potatoes—other vegetable—plum pudding—bread—butter.** Those present my brother and his hired man, our hired man, my husband and myself.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

No, we always had enough to eat even in the dry thirties. Our garden was surrounded by trees and the grasshoppers did not harm it or our rhubarb patch.
15. TRAPPING AND OWNERS

When I was young and living in our own home bandana
but we didn't have much to eat. We had to make do with
whatever we could find. We would go out into the woods
and hunt for food. We would also go fishing.

Breakfast - porridge, oatmeal, milk, bread, butter.

Luncheon - potato salad, vegetable, rice pudding, milk.

Dinner - roast chicken, potatoes, other vegetables, plum pudding,
bread, butter. Those were good times.

20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

(i) We try to have more variation in the meals. During the winter we can buy lettuce and celery also oranges and grapefruit. Oranges in the early years were a great luxury and usually only seen at Christmas. Lettuce and celery only used in summer.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

I still make my own bread, butter and other baking. We have our own vegetables in basement besides what is canned.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. [Use back of page if more space is needed].

I can remember my grandmother and grandfather making cheese in the early days, using the end of a heavy log to press it. Grandmother had a shelf in the milk house for the cheeses. She always made her own soft soap, wood ashes for lye. Red River bannock was a great delicacy, there was plenty of wild fruit—strawberries, raspberries, saskatoons, plums, chokecherries—cranberries, these being made into jelly and jam. The Indians used to bring up blue berries from Lake Winnipeg in their boats and you could get a good pailful for 50¢.

The old store at Lower Fort Garry used to have hard tack, a cake about the size of a pie plate, made of flour and water we thought very hard but we liked them. We also liked their fruit biscuits, a square cookie with currants in them, sometimes they tasted very gritty, the currants not being well cleaned.
